talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I spent a lot of time laughing at them then. I don't now. I think there are some Republican Secretaries of State, and absolutely some Republican AGs, who would adopt the "he wasn't born under the jurisdiction of the US so not a NBC" argument and disqualify if it was happening now.

talk.author: did:plc:np6i4w2m3vyq6r4zc664e4t2
talk.utter: Except, of course, Honolulu in 1961 was as much the US as Washington, DC. The Panama Canal Zone, by contrast, was not.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Yes. There were arguments made based on his father's status, and which did not rest on his birthplace.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Yes. There were arguments made based on his father's status, and which did not rest on his birthplace.

talk.author: did:plc:np6i4w2m3vyq6r4zc664e4t2
talk.utter: And yet, remarkably, the 14th Amendment Section 1 doesn't mention parents!

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
It also doesn't use the phrase "natural born."

There is not exactly a wealth of case law on whether "natural born" and "citizen at birth" are synonymous.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I spent a lot of time laughing at them then. I don't now. I think there are some Republican Secretaries of State, and absolutely some Republican AGs, who would adopt the "he wasn't born under the jurisdiction of the US so not a NBC" argument and disqualify if it was happening now.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: That's why I'm as concerned as I am about the extent of due process for disqualification. And why I lean so heavily into "same as a criminal conviction" as the minimum.

talk.author: did:plc:s5fi6htc7xhnshxxn37dg65c
talk.utter: I understand, but here’s my thing: I would never have adopted so restrictive a procedure 10 years ago, and I think it’s only being suggested now because we all know the center isn’t holding.

talk.author: did:plc:s5fi6htc7xhnshxxn37dg65c
talk.utter: I don’t think we can make the center hold. I think people who come up with loads of process to try and knit things together are acting in good faith but process can’t save when substance is gone.

talk.author: did:plc:s5fi6htc7xhnshxxn37dg65c
talk.utter:
There is not anything we can do that is going to prevent them from reaching for bad faith things that put democracy out of reach. 

So now what?

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I don't know. Wish I did.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I spent a lot of time laughing at them then. I don't now. I think there are some Republican Secretaries of State, and absolutely some Republican AGs, who would adopt the "he wasn't born under the jurisdiction of the US so not a NBC" argument and disqualify if it was happening now.

talk.author: did:plc:jtir3tfw5lgp34t7akdbwgkl
talk.utter:
There were in fact lawsuits about it.

The Maine SoS can point to an actual court case concluding that the fascist is a seditionist; there was no court case concluding that Obama was not a natural-born citizen.

(I am not expecting ME's or CO's decisions to stand, mind you.)

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
Yes, I know. I worked on one of those cases as a law clerk, and attended hearings in others.

But I'm not sure which court case, other than the Colorado one, you're referring to for Trump.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
Yes, I know. I worked on one of those cases as a law clerk, and attended hearings in others.

But I'm not sure which court case, other than the Colorado one, you're referring to for Trump.

talk.author: did:plc:jtir3tfw5lgp34t7akdbwgkl
talk.utter: I am in fact referring to the Colorado one.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Which was a ballot challenge case conducted on a short timeline that did not offer Trump the same ability to collect or present evidence that he would have had even in a normal civil case, much less a criminal one.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Gonna be interesting to see if they can agree on a reason, though.

talk.author: did:plc:6hit5rjdbmlnscmuk4bbtmuc
talk.utter: you think Roberts tries to go a direction other than the Thomas/Alito wing is looking for?

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I think it's plausible that this gets up to 9 votes to overturn, based on three or four differentmajor lines of reasoning. We could wind up with a five-page per curiam, and 2-1-3-2-1-4-2 opinions, with some of those numbers being "join except as to part __" or "join only as to parts ___"

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I think it's plausible that this gets up to 9 votes to overturn, based on three or four differentmajor lines of reasoning. We could wind up with a five-page per curiam, and 2-1-3-2-1-4-2 opinions, with some of those numbers being "join except as to part __" or "join only as to parts ___"

talk.author: did:plc:vhnofjzwopl6r2u637ulossv
talk.utter: In a SCOTUS first, a justice will inadvertently dissent with themselves

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I'm not entirely sure that would be a SCOTUS first, honestly.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
So the issue here is that there are two different ways (two main ways, anyway) that AI can infringe: the input used for training can be infringing, or the output can be.

Right now, I'm talking about the input - can you just copy stuff into the AI and call it "reading."

talk.author: did:plc:t7ayphiew2kysdunfu6xm2at
talk.utter: I take the digital book out from the library and feed the text right into the LLM. The LLM isn't copying the text, just reading it and processing it, same as I would do. How is that illegal.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: How does the LLM, which is a software program, "read" the text without copying the text into memory? Note: it is not necessary to *store* the text for there to be a copy.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Do you have a case for that?

talk.author: did:plc:2h5yo2dhkdo6r3tokotdqu3v
talk.utter: I realize law and reality are wholly different things, but I would be very angry if a legal ruling is based on "being in memory" vs "streamed text". The technical distinction is absurd.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Oh, I'd have to reread it to be sure, but I think I can think of at least one case that holds streaming to be infringing.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: The bit where you photocopy all the books and take the copies home to do the work. For starters.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
And is there a *legal* distinction between a program that scans public tweets for the use of racial slurs and counts them, for purposes of proving social media is home to racists, and performing the same scan, but using it for a language model?

Is the scraping the crime? Or how it's used? Both?

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
For LLMs, there's an argument that the training use provides information about what words are found near which other words. Which is why some are convinced that LLM training is fair.

But the output competes w/ the original. So I'm not as convinced. I think it's a coin-flip.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
For LLMs, there's an argument that the training use provides information about what words are found near which other words. Which is why some are convinced that LLM training is fair.

But the output competes w/ the original. So I'm not as convinced. I think it's a coin-flip.

talk.author: did:plc:yczklumppl3ufxub2t47hrgw
talk.utter: What's the "output" of the training, tho? You seem to be jumping to "works produced via the model". But arguably, it's just "the model". (I.e., I think its worth considering "using the model to make something substantially similar to an existing work" as a separate infringement issue.)

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
I think that's where the fight is. Is the only thing that matters the software that is produced through training, or does the ultimate purpose of that software matter? 

Given Warhol, I really don't feel comfortable hanging my hat on the assumption that the ultimate purpose is irrelevant.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: The bit where you photocopy all the books and take the copies home to do the work. For starters.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
And is there a *legal* distinction between a program that scans public tweets for the use of racial slurs and counts them, for purposes of proving social media is home to racists, and performing the same scan, but using it for a language model?

Is the scraping the crime? Or how it's used? Both?

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
It's not the kind of infringement likely to be a crime. 

But the use is the important factor - because an unlicensed copy is infringement unless the use is excused (eg by fair use). Generally, indexing to provide information about things is fair use. Uses that compete with originals usually isn't.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
It's not the kind of infringement likely to be a crime. 

But the use is the important factor - because an unlicensed copy is infringement unless the use is excused (eg by fair use). Generally, indexing to provide information about things is fair use. Uses that compete with originals usually isn't.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
My wife is reminding me I have to go get groceries, which takes precedence.

I think you're correct in that it's the OUTPUT that's at issue, legally AND morally. And another aspect of it is *scale*. Even if the process is not problematic by hand, it can become so when it's done a million times.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: It's both input and output.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: The bit where you photocopy all the books and take the copies home to do the work. For starters.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
But I'm not photocopying them. I'm checking out a digital copy and then running the text through a very simple analyzer. I could write it in a day.

Does it matter if I buy the digital copy, instead of checking it out?

Or if I scan my own physical copy?

Or count by hand and make notes on paper?

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Copying into memory - even just into RAM - is still a copy. That's black-letter law. Your right to make that copy is limited to the rights provided by the license. So, probably it doesn't matter whether it's bought or checked-out, because in either case the use is outside the scope of the license.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Copying into memory - even just into RAM - is still a copy. That's black-letter law. Your right to make that copy is limited to the rights provided by the license. So, probably it doesn't matter whether it's bought or checked-out, because in either case the use is outside the scope of the license.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter: In the future, there may be an eBook TOS saying I'm not allowed to count how many times the word "fuck" appears in a book, but now, there isn't. I'm not copying the book into memory: I'm counting words. The book is not copied, except in the same way it's "copied" to my screen as I read it.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
That's not how licensing works. 

You don't have a license to do anything that isn't forbidden by the license. You only have a license to do the things expressly permitted.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Judges - even the more political ones - aren't generally very concerned with whether an outcome in a specific case is "favourable to the broader conservative side" because of who the litigant is. Things that involve shaping big policy, sure. "Will this be a nice news cycle for Elon," not so much.

talk.author: did:plc:eaxgzdvtvnsl4ambjx3j5kv6
talk.utter: With an ideologically highly motivated judge, does that apply in terms of who the defendant is, as well? Media Matters is a thorn in the side of Right Wingers-e.g. Ken Paxton, and it's their business model that's being sued over.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: No, those are individual issues, not policy outcomes.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: No, those are individual issues, not policy outcomes.

talk.author: did:plc:eaxgzdvtvnsl4ambjx3j5kv6
talk.utter: I just perceive that Judge Cannon is doing whatever she can to facilitate Trump's individual issues-not really ruling on natsec policy law or classification as much as giving him what he wants & gumming up the prosecution. (It is criminal rather than civil, however)

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Cannon is an exceptional case, even by modern standards. Which is why the 11th was a bit abrupt with her.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Cannon is an exceptional case, even by modern standards. Which is why the 11th was a bit abrupt with her.

talk.author: did:plc:eaxgzdvtvnsl4ambjx3j5kv6
talk.utter: Right, but she's still on the case, making rulings about the CIPA hearings & scheduling that are making the nat'l security lawyers jaws drop. Very careful to avoid provoking interlocutory appeals however. In MuskvMedia Matters I wonder whether the judge'll just let the litigation run a long time.

talk.author: did:plc:eaxgzdvtvnsl4ambjx3j5kv6
talk.utter: Musk, having deeper pockets, would win by staying in court for 6 months or a year before dropping the suit, for instance.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: I'd anticipate that the case stays in court for at least that long no matter who the judge is.
